Hillsdale, Mich: July 15, 1893
My dear Aunt Anna:
We were so very
glad to get your good letter day be-
fore yesterday. The postman went 
right by at first and said he had
nothing for us but he came back 
in a few minutes with the letter
raging that he had forgotten it.
I return Mrs. Jones' letter, which
I am very much obliged to you 
for getting for me and to - Eddie 
for letting me read. What a
dear, sweet soul she is! I am
so sorry she has business troubles
and can imagine [just?] how she 
deprives herself in order to help
that little grand-daughter. She 
evidently wishes that she could

release us from our note, when we
ought really to be paying back all
that she let us have.

    I am very glad that she doesn't

let Eddie pay back any that he had.

 We are all quite wilted and nearly

melted by the weather this week.

I hope you have ^not the conscience to

be chilly these days. If you have,
I can boast over you for I have
even laid aside my inseparable
companion the faithful old red
shawl.Mrs Davis and Ida even
in last night and they facetiously
asked me if I had to have a
fire, these days Lizzie heartlessly
remarked that I managed to get
along with the kitchen fire.
Well, you and I are fellow sufferers
in this cold and cruel world .We
can sympathize with each other and
exchange shiver for shiver can't we?

 Many thanks for the Pulsatilla. I was

not suffering for it. but thought I

would like to have it on hand
Lizzie did not have any, but there
was enough in the little package
for us both. The Aldriches are
living on Prof. Gurney's house now, 
while they are away for the summer

 Bennie came over last night

and invited Eva and me down
there. We had a nice little visit,
and some ice-cream. They were much
surprised to hear of Eddie's marriage.

 I attended Nettie Dunn's wedding

last Wednesday night There was
a large company there, mostly
people from College Hill. Nettie
looked very sweet in white
silk. and the green was nice-
looking. Prof. Dunn performed
the ceremony, and did it in his
happiest vein. There were a
great many very useful and
beautiful presents. Holden sent down
a ["Soo"?] souvenir spoon for me to
take. She had three dozen solid silver

tea-spoons, besides several souvenir
and berry spoons.

    I expect to take the steamer for

home, Monday evening, July 24th
Yes see my visit is "long-drawn-
out" but both of my physicians
have advised it, Dr. Moore thinks
I ought to stay all summer. but
Holden thinks he has lived alone
about as long as he can. I have
been improving very fast since I
went to see Dr. Andrews.

I wish Aunt Mary could have made

John and Azia a little visit. It was
nice she caught a glimpse of him.
We will write to her soon. I think
that John and Azia are planning
to go home with me. I shall be very
glad of their company. We shall
hope to hear from you after.

 Please give my love to Eddie, Ella

and the children. and accept a
large share for your precious self.

            Very lovingly,    Hattie

Sault Ste-Marie Michigan
                           September 11th . 1893

My Dear Aunt Anna:

                 It seems a

long, long time since we have heard
from you. Very likely it is my
own fault but that, you know,
doesn't make it any easier to
bear. We have been at home now
nearly seven weeks. The first four
weeks, John and Azia and Clarence
spent with us. Then soon after they
left, we all went down the river
about thirty miles to Sailor's
Encampment to spend a couple
of weeks with the Johnston girls,
of whom I told you, their Indian
descent etc. They have a little
shanty of two rooms right near
the river and also a "lodge"
made of hemlock and birch bark

The shanty was given up to us
at night, while the girls occupied
the lodge, and their father and 
mother and brother occupied
tents.Their brother, "Howard"
has charge of the range lights
along the river for which he re -
ceives fifty dollars a month,
as long as the boats are running
It was pleasant being in sight
of the river, where we saw so
many large steamers and barges
constantly passing. Holden count
ed thirty-six one day, and didn't
see nearly all them. He and Eva
went fishing several time
and Eva proved to be the best
fisherman. She caught seventeen
perch one day, while Holden only 
caught one. Eva got a large
pike on her hook one day, but 
when they tried to get it into
the boat, it broke the line, and

carried off hook sinkers and all.
They have no regular services
on the Island, so Holden preached 
both Sunday evenings that we 
were there. I had a hard cold 
all the time I was there, and 
was sick abed twice, with chills 
and fever. We came back sooner 
than we expected on this account.
I don't know what I should 
have done if I had not had 
that dose of medicine you [illegible] 
up for me, for there was no 
doctor within reach. These little 
pellets soon relieved me however,  
and I think my faith was 
strengthened a good deal, as 
well as my body. I had to 
laugh at Miss Johnston [illegible] 
(in my sleeve), for she took ^two of 
those smallest pellets of Arsenicum, 
just to see how it tasted, and 
she said it made her feel sick 
all night.

Since we came home, I have been feeling
a good deal better, thought my cold
and cough still trouble me.
My stay at Hillsdale did me so 
much good. I didn't feel like the 
same person when I came back. 
I have a good girl in the kitchen 
now, so hope to keep from get
ting so run down again.
I wonder if Aunt Mary is beginning
to think about coming back from
the east, and what you are
planning to do this fall and
winter. I hope you will stay in
the state, for you are so near and 
dear to us we want you within
visiting distance! We hope to 
be nearer you all, sometime.
We all [join?] in very much love
to you, and to Eddie and family
Eva is planning to answer
[Jaidee's?] dear little letter, before
long. Very lovingly, as ever,
Hattie

[Written across the top:]
year. We regret
it very much but
Frank is obliged
to get there as soon
as possible on ac
count of his business
and it is considera-
ble cheaper going
that way. We hate
to lose them terribly,

Claire but it can't

Hillsdale, Michigan
June 24th, 18[76?]
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                  I believe I am

owing you a letter, am I not? At any
rate it is time I was, so I guess I will
write and give you a chance to make
me. It is over a week now since Com-
mencement, but I don't seem to get
much rested. Perhaps I am "constitu-
tionally tired", but I guess I shall
feel better after our journey we are
thinking of making. And I must tell
you about Utah. We expect to leave
here the tenth of July and go first
to Washington, where we shall stop
a few days, and then go to Philadelphia

and spend one or two weeks there,
then to New York city for a day or
two, and then [triple underlined] to Remsen [underlined], which
I think will be nicest of all.
So we shall see you about the 
last of July. We are going with a 
family, Mr. Winson's people, and
some other, and expect to enjoy
it very much. Father thinks the
journey will do mother and me
good, and I think a good deal the
same myself! Indeed, I don't know
but I was the first one who sug-
gested it!--However I think dear
old Remsen will be the crowning
point of all and I expect to look
forward to that with longing and
almost impatience, through the weeks
spent at other places. I want to
gain ten pounds while I am gone

for I only weigh ninety pounds now
and I have weighed ninety-nine, and
I was the lightest one in our class.
My greatest ambition is to weigh a
hundred and ten, but I never ex-
pect to attain to that. It is well
to have high aims in life though_
You wouldn't guess that I was an
Alumna of Hillsdale College, and
a "B.S.", to read such nonsense,
would you? But actually, I didn't
see any difference, when I came down
from the stage after speaking my
little piece and receiving my diplo-
ma, I didn't feel a bit metamor-
phosed into anything, or anybody
very wise or big, but just the same
little goose I always was. I don't 
think graduating is a farce though
by any means, I got four bouquets.

Mother wants me to take my exercises with
me and inflict them on you. I don't know
though, I like you pretty well and I haven't
hardly the heart too [second o crossed out]. Perhaps if you want
to you can buy me off with onions after
I get there.     Frank came out to see
me graduate after all. He couldn't stay
away when the time came, but I shall
want to see him just as much at Rem-
sen for he only staid here three days
as he had to go back on account of
an old yearly meeting of his.
I do hope they will have a camp
meeting at [Trenton?] while we are there,
so we can go. Do you suppose Aunt
Mary can come home while we are
there? I hope so. Perhaps she can come
with us right from New York. How nice
that would be. Frank and Lizzie start
for Lewiston Wednesday. They go through
Canada, so they will not be able to visit

[written across the top]: none sure [underlined], and when
I do write I
at least have
the pleasure of
expecting an an-
swer, whether it
comes or not.
We all sympa-
thize very much
with Grandma, I do
hope she will be
more comfortable
soon-   Aren't you
all tired of the cold
weather? Michigan
is the state for me!
With much love to all,
and expecially yours lovingly,
Hattie
Hillsdale, Michigan,
January [?], 1877_
My Dear Aunt Jennie:_

                                      I have a letter

commenced to you in my writing desk, but {struck through]
dated December 28th, but I can't finish
it for the last sentence written is only
just begun and I can't think for my
life what it was I was going to say!
So you see I have made a new start.
Whether I am able to finish ths with
out interruption, I do not know now as
well as you will when you receive it.

    The only thing of importance that I

said in the unfinished sheet was that
I could not tell how it happened that
I had left your last letter so long un
answered, and come to consider it, that
was not of much importance either, for
it would be hard for anyone to tell

how I could neglect such a super extra
good letter. I expected when I received
it to answer it immediately, and 
perhaps that was the very reason why I 
didn't, for father says "the unexpected
always takes place".  But then you 
know I have been sick too, and the
others have written so often that I
have thought I could send a little
"anytime", and I am beginning to learn
that "anytime" most generally means
"never".  Those things that are in the
most danger of never being accomplish
ed are such as can be done "anytime",
don't you think so? We are all appall-
ed just now by the news of that terrible
railroad disaster in Ohio. How pecu-
liarly sad seems the death of so widely
renowned a man as P.P. Bliss, with
all his family, and yet how few doubt
less, were as well prepared as they.

    Two young ladies here in College re

ceived word yesterday that their father

was on the ill-fated train, coming to
spend New Year's with them.

    Many are still in suspence as to

whether they have lost friends or not.,
it seems dreadful to think of.

                          I have been meaning to

write to some of you ever since Aunt
Sarah and Uncle Will came out, to
influence you to send them a letter
at least every other day. At first
they couldn't seem reconciled to not
receive one every mail and if wrung
my heart to see them disappointed so
often, but now I think they are con-
tented if two[underline]) come every[underlined] other[underlined] day[underlined]. Now
don't think I am writing this to tease
them!     I often wonder if their
letters seem as few and far between
to you, as yours do here. It seems
strange the mails are so irregular, and
play such tricks with the letter's.

    We have made us a new game

that we have lots of fun playing. I think

John[something struck through] Eddie would like it. Johnnie
wrote five Alphabets on (five times twenty
six) squares of pasteboard, putting each
letter on both sides of the square, and
this we mix them all up and each one
selects letters for any word he thinks
of, then disarrange them and change.
One wouldn't think it would be so
difficult to tell what word was in
tended when all the letters are there.
Do you like such ways of passing an
evening occasionally?  I suppose Aunt
Sarah wrote you about the Christmas
Tree at the church, we went to see.
It was the first (and only) festival of
its kind I have attended in Hillsdale.

  Don't you think Aunt Anna better

ask me directly what makes me so
still instead of making roundabout
inquiries, especially when she owes
me a letter?  However I am not going
to keep still any longer, if doesn't pay.
for when I write no letters I receive

[written across the top]:
use of my molasses
than you do!
The idea of try-
ing to black the 
stove with it
You must have
imagined the fumes[underlined]
would reach Uncle
Will and help
his Asthma. Per
haps that was[underlined] it
I believe he was a
little better about
that time!
There! There! Shut up
the stove! I am[underlined] go
ing to close! Very
hastily, but as ever
lovingly - Hattie
Hillsdale, Michigan
January 20th, 1877
My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                 I am completely

overwhelmed with gratitute and astonish
ment at your promptness in answering my
letter. And so you see I am hastening to
write again lest you may all feel kind
of lost in knowing that you are not ow-
inw me a letter. It would be an unheard
of state of things for none of you to be
owing me, wouldn't it!  I have been
thinking seriously since yesterday of chal-
lenging Aunt Mary to a poetry[underlined] match[underlined].
I know I could write more than four
lines if I got such an inspiration as
she evidently had. If I was the Muse
of Poetry I wouldn't visit her again
unless she could pay me better than
that for my trouble. But of course her

machine may have broken after such
a strain. Tell her I think she ought
to be careful about publishing this until
she gets a copyright for it might lead
to a dispute as to the authorship of
it. If Longfellow or Bryant should
claim it there might be difficulty in
convincing the world that it came from
an (as yet) obscure and unknown
poet. In such a case I think I should
feel it my duty to come forward and
tell the world frankly that I wrote
it. That wouldn't be true, of course, but
it would be heroic, now wouldn't it,
to admit that you wrote such a thing!
Well I'll have Aunt Mary sending me
some [quieting?] powders that aren't all
sugar if I say much more. So I will
continue my letter to you, I guess.
I must confess that Johnnie writes very
few letters except to Ohio, but what
can the poor fellow do with a letter
coming an average every other day

and no one to answer them but
himself! Uncle Will and I have
repeatedly offered our services both
in noting the contents and returning
answers to the letters but so blind
is he to his own interests that he rejects
our offers every time. I hardly know
what to tell you of the person who so
occupies his attention, for I fear I
may be repeating what you have al
ready heard from other sources.
But I fancy if Aunt Sarah could
be persuaded to remain here until
spring she would have the pleasure
of receiving another neice into the family.
It will be nice for me to have a 
sister again, will it not! Ah, but
no one can fill little Lizzie's place!

    Oh I do hope you and Aunt Anna

and Grandma will come and make
us a good long visit next summer.
It would be perfectly delightful!

And I would show you what a nice
little housekeeper I shall be by that time!
Bring John Eddie along too, and then
perhaps I can go through my cook-book
in order, as I have so often wished to
do. It will be so nice to have some
one to eat up the things when I don't
have very good luck.  There, I 
didn't mean to scare anybody. Tell
John Eddie to come and I won't do
any such barbarous thing. It was
horrid of me to think of it. We shall
have the cream of the land,_churned,_
that will be the nicest kind or butter-
milk you see. But I believe my
letter is really rising above its usual
height of absurdity, and I must close
before you get quite to the [point?] of using
my letter[struck through] ^it as a persuader to the fire.
I made some delicious gingersnaps yes-
terday. Won't you have one? Uncle Will
ate the biggest one there was and then
said they weren't good. Can you imagine
my emotions?--You see I make a better

[embossed rose at top of page]

         Hillsdale, Febr^uary 3rd, 1877

My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                Your last letter

created quite a stir in our usually quiet
household. I mean your last letter to
me. It made us all laugh heartily at
Johnnie's expense. I think many such
letters would exasperate him into turn
ing his attention in your direction. This
one would doubtless at any other time
than within four weeks of his wedding.

    Won't it be nice for me to have a

sister again? I expect it will be just
like Johnnie to monopolize her though

don't you? He has just come from
town and brought the second number
of [Moody and Sankey's--struck through] P. P. Bliss and Sankey's Hymn Book. One
piece in it "The Changing Bells of Time" I 
heard sung most beautifully by an
Evangelist who was here [last--struck through] the first
part of this week. His name is Spencer
and he has the richest sweetest voice
nearly that I ever heard. The meetings
here continue to be very interesting.
Thirty arose for prayers at one time.
Many are young people, and some quite
advanced in life.

    Tell Aunt Sarah that Mr. Childs is

selling all his goods at a reduced
rate, thouh they are not injured in
the least by smoke or anything else.

I got mother some seventy-five cent
flannel for sixty cents, so you see
the reduction isn't very much though it
is worth[underlined] accepting[underlined].  Tell Uncle Will
that Mr. [Goolly's?] wife is in here now and
she is as cool[underlined] as he, besides being decid-
edly more talkative and it's enough to
drive anyone frantic who is trying to
write a sensible[underlined] letter, as you
know mine always are! I must
tell you how smart mother and I were
this morning. We had breakfast at
half past seven and after that we
cleared up the breakfast dishes, filled
the lamps, made the beds, put the
chicken on to boil, cooked some
squash and made five large pies

before ten o'clock. Then after that
I made biscuitts[second t struck through] and got dinner.
Mother has been clear out to the gate
this afternoon. I think we are getting
along realy nicely. There is a new pro-
prietor in the Laundry here now and
we get our clothes more regularly than
we did. One of the Professors here in 
College, Mr. Fisk, has been obliged to
go to his old home in New Hampshire
on account of his health. We went Tues
day, so if Uncle Will had only waited
one day he might have had some of 
most "original" company he ever met.
Can't you and Aunt Anna come out
at Commencement time? I wish you
could. Please write soon. Lovingly, Hattie

[cross-written across top]:
our weeks seem to
be nowadays.
Mary is real
good help. She
does our washing
and ironing now.
You don't know
how much I want
to see you all or
even any of you.
Sometimes it seems
as though I must.
I know so little and
have so many per-
plexities, and nobody
to go to. Please
write when you can
Auntie Dear.
Ever Lovingly, Hattie.

                       Hillsdale, June [20th?] 1877

My Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                                 Nothing but the

hurry and complete occupation of Com
mencement week could have kept me
from writing and acknowledging those
beautiful forgetmenots the day I re-
ceived them. They came Wednesday
morning, just the right time, and I
put them down cellar in water im-
mediately and they revived and be-
came as sweet and fresh as could
be desired. I showed them to the lady
at the greenhouse and she said they
were entirely different from any she
ever saw. They were admired by all
who saw them and I am most obliged

for your kindness than I can tell you.
I fear though that you robbed your-
selves, I had no idea of your sending
so many. I must tell you about
those plants you sent me when you
first went back too. The forget-
menot, daisy, white pansy, and 
that fine green vine with a yellow
flower, are all in blossom and
growing like everything. Our flower-
seeds didn't come up very well so
we are all the gladder of those lit-
tle plants. Those plants that you
rooted from [slips?] while here are
nearly all living and doing well.
Both my vines are running up
on trellis and [illegible] as fast as
ever they can, and the begonia is
flourishing finely. You mustnt
think that this dreadful writing is
from my gold pen Aunt Jennie.

I am writing with a steel pen this
morning because I am in a tearing
hurry and am afraid of hurting the
gold one. I do not mean to break
that as I did my other. Do you know
I just finished my black cambric
dress about a week ago. Wasn't I
slow?  But there were so many things
to hinder me. It looks just as pretty
as can be. Made in a [Lolasaise?] and
trimmed with fine knife pleating. I
cut it and all. Did you get to [South?]
Hadley? Or are you going, or are you
there now? I have forgotten the time
of the reunion. You know the reunions
here are in '80, and one of the A-
lumni who came back to Com-
mencement made me promise
that if neither of us were married
then I would attend the reunion
[letter struck out] suffer with him. Only think of

[of--struck through] making such an engagement three
years beforehand. He is Principal
of a High School in an Ohio city,
and expects to go to Europe next
year. I am going to the lake with
him this afternoon, and it will be
a perfect time to be on the water
if it continues as pleasant as now.
Are you as much afraid of these
row-boats as Uncle Will, or do
you enjoy such fun as much as
I? We are going to commence can-
ning strawberries today and expect
to have these nearly every day this
week. Then a carpenter is coming
tomorrow to make those two back
chambers into one and we have
trunks and boxes and feather-
beds and everything else (you re-
member) to take care of. So you
see it will be a busy week as all

[cross-written across top]:
drowned once-
I should like
to go every week
and learn to
row. Tell Uncle 
Will when he gets
a farm he must
remember and
have a pond in
the middle
of it and
then I will
come and
see him.
But I must close
and go do something
more profitable[underlined]
Love to all

          from,
                Hattie

Hillsdale, July 4th, 1877
Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                        Here it is only nine

o'clock in the morning and we have the
work all done up until it is time to
get dinner, and I have practiced my
music for today, and all because
we got up so early. You see being the
"glorious Fourth" we couldn't sleep
for the bells and guns and crackers.
Johnnie fired crackers through the 
blinds of their chamber window be-
fore any of us were up, and then he
tied some on the end of a pole and 
let them off close by my window.
Wasn't that dignified proceeding,
for a College Professor?!

I remember very well that it isn't
my turn to write you Aunt Jennie,
but it seems so long since we have
heard from Remsen that I feel im
pelled to stir you up a little and
find out if you are all asleep.
We wrote to Aunt Mary yesterday.
I suppose she will be in New York
all summer, will she not?
Azia expects to go to Ohio next
week to visit her friends. She
will stay three or four weeks and then
Johnnie wil go for her. I think I 
shall stay at home like a good girl
most of the summer and keep my
fun for next year. Father and I are
planning for a nice trip then if
everything goes right. We have just
been loving those two small back
chambers made into one and John
nie and Azia are going to love

that and we shall fix up the front
room for a spare chamber. So
any time after the middle of July
we shall be ready to receive guests.
Now is the time to speak for accom
modations! How many shall I 
enter from [Steuben?]? I have been
getting me some cloth for a white
overdress. It is quite pretty and I 
cut and made the overskirt yes-
terday with the exception of the trim-
ming which will be Hamburg edge.
You see I am getting smart, it does
not take me six months to ^finish any-
thing, any more. Mary has gone home
to spend the Fourth, went last
night and will be back tonight.
She does our washing and ironing
now and is real faithful about the
work. Did you go to your class re-
union as you thought of? We had

a letter from Frank and Lizzie the
other day saying that they thought come
of coming out at Christmas to 
spend the Holidays with us. Would-
n't it be lovely if they could?
Darling little Claire said that she
was writing to her "dear, good, dear,
sweet, Auntie Hattie". But they
didn't send the letter. I thought it
was too bad. Frank said she im-
proved a great deal while she was
out here. Father and I, Johnnie and
Azia, and Professor Haynes and his 
wife all went down to Bawbeese
Lake last week and spent the after-
noon. We took our baskets of good
things with us and had our supper
in the grove. Father didn't like to 
go on the [?] but the rest of
us went in a round boat too.
I have been down this a num-
ber of times lately and haven't been

[cross-written across top]:
It makes me very
sad to think of
your home bereft
as ours is of a pre
cious mother. But
each loss draws us
nearer to each other
and nearer to our
Heavenly Father.

    We shall none of us

have many more part
ings for we shall each
be called ourselves. 
If I can only be as well
prepared as you all are
I shall not dread the
summons.

                                Hillsdale, Michigan
                                                   March 23rd, 1878

Dear Aunt Jennie:-

                             Your letters were

very gladly received yesterday and I am
sorry that I must answer in such a
hurry, but father wants to take [this?] to
the office at ten and so I have only about
half an hour to write in. I have been
pretty closely occupied this week as there
has been a musical convention held
in town and I have attended every eve-
ning, and either morning or afternoon
of each day. I went three times the 
first day but found that it was too
much for me. Professor L. O. Emerson
of Boston conducted it, and last even
ing we closed with a concert which went

off very nicely. Professor Emerson as you
know is a great composer of music and
he gave us excellent instructions, dwelling
particularly upon the importance, in sing-
ing, of light and shade, proper expression,
and the distinct articulation of words.

    I went into Court one afternoon this week

for the first time in my life. There were
several ladies in, and although the case
was not particularly interesting, one of
a chattel mortage, I enjoyed it being so
new to me.
